item.title: Why make things simple / the Douglas Adams principle
item.description:
Douglas Adams said:

â€œI am rarely happier than when spending an entire day programming my computer to perform automatically a task that would otherwise take me a good ten seconds to do by hand.â€

This is exactly the kind of productivity thinking the country needs, I think. Iâ€™ve been trying to follow his example recently. I am trying to disassemble how I do things / why Iâ€™m doing them / whether I should I just sit in my pants all day eating pringles / what sort of task-environment-brain re-jigs might help answer any of those questions. This is leading to many â€œall day programming for a ten second taskâ€ moments.

Itâ€™s all part of joining in the currently very fashionable and exciting pastime of â€œwondering what kind of brain I have and whether it really needs to have been so bloody difficult all this time.â€ (Analogy: as a left-hander, if Iâ€™d always been made to use my right hand, as was the case pre 1950ish.) Coming at it like a design problem, prototyping things that may end up on the scrapheap, is the only way.

So rather than get on with, say, actually working on the sci-fi book or writing about anything concrete, Iâ€™ve done the following:

  • Made this blog using Quarto in R and linked it to buttondown for subscribers. Autonomy! Open source! No readers!
  • Read a bunch about distributed knowledge systems and brain diversity, leading to â€“>
  • Moving to Obsidian for all note-taking / thinking stuff (itâ€™s a delight to use, if youâ€™re already a bit markdown-leaning, and again it lets you have transparent control over all your stuff; it can also do lovely clever things like collate tasks from all sources).
  • Using Obsidianâ€™s Digital Garden plugin to host exobrain.coveredinbees.org via Vercel autopushing to Github, setting a YAML property to dg-publish for any md file I want live (what a super, pretentious two-decades-old-type word â€˜exobrainâ€™ is: see the ngrams, pic below also - it actually peaked in 2010, though its first ngrams appearance is in 1970, Arthur B. Bronwellâ€™s â€˜Science and Technology in the World of the Futureâ€™: â€œto carry out manâ€™s informational processing demands in much the same way that an exoskeleton carries out his powerful tasks.â€)
  • Then thereâ€™s a nice little obsidian-to-quarto plugin. Err why? Because just blogging in Quarto, Iâ€™d have to manually add exobrain URLs myself, which would take me a good ten seconds by hand, so instead I (and chatGPT) made some R functions that check for Obsidian exports and, if present, convert all Obsidian internal links to exobrain URLs, as well as reformatting the YAML so the tags work correctly. So for example I can use Obsidianâ€™s own internal link system (which has very smooth autofind) to connect to exobrain bits (e.g. a list of starter questions connecting magic, the money system and â€˜the gameâ€™).

So now the process of writing a blog post couldnâ€™t be simpler. I just (1) write it in Obsidian as Iâ€™m doing now; (2) use the Obsidian-to-Quarto export function; (3) in RStudio, run the R function to convert exobrain links and YAML and move the files; (4) when in a state Iâ€™m happy to publish, move it manually to the posts folder (that could be streamlined); (5) run â€˜renderâ€™ on that final post in RStudio so the HTML goes to the docs folder; (6) git stage/commit and push in Gitraken to get it live on coveredinbees. Done! Just like that. Substack schmubschmack.

Sigh. I am reminded a little of the Mars Curiosity Roverâ€™s landing plan (in one of my all time favourite youtube videos, recorded before they knew whether it would succeed). Aim for a flat spot, use Marsâ€™ atmosphere to slow down a little (itâ€™s 1% the density of Earthâ€™s), use a huge parachute, release a cap to view the ground, drop the rover carried by its own rocket stage because none of that can slow it down enough, but you canâ€™t use rockets to land because the dust will bugger the roverâ€™s systems - so hover above the ground and lower it on four wires, and then boost the rocket stage off to the side so it doesnâ€™t crash on top of the now-on-Mars Curiosity. Oh and do all that entirely automatically because signals to Mars were a 14 minute round trip at the time. Done! Just like that. Elon Schmelon.

Hereâ€™s Jazz-student turned NASA entry/descent/landing lead Adam Steltzner:

â€œWhen people look at it, it looks crazy. Thatâ€™s a very natural thing. Sometimes when we look at it, it looks crazy. It is the result of reasoned engineering thought. But it still looks crazy.â€

Reasoned engineering thought, though, takes a lot of testing. The problem with testing human brains, or at least mine, is the tendency to default to â€œyouâ€™re just a useless idiotâ€ and stop at that, rather than taking little steps, inching forward, playing, trying new things, seeing what goes with the grain, what rubs against it. It needs resetting daily as the self-blame module can be deeply wired in - previous perceived failures obviously a personal failure, says the module, rather than allowing consideration of the whole you/task/environment setup1.

So while Iâ€™m obviously getting those sweet sweet Douglas Adams Dopamine Hits from all this ridiculous tinkering, itâ€™sâ€¦ not entirely ridiculous. None of this is novel - hereâ€™s a nice writeup of the general digital garden idea, itâ€™s in that ballpark. The world is littered with failed â€˜Systems That Will Solve Everythingâ€™, but maybe thereâ€™s merit in this kind of slow, tentative gardening.

All the â€˜digital gardenâ€™ tech is allowing is easy linkage - itâ€™s been described as â€˜your own personal wikipediaâ€™. But replicating existing links would seem pointless, no? So the test here is: can it be used to add little modular chunks, questions, connections? In a way that isnâ€™t just building an ideas oubliette? What, if anything, can it really add?

Iâ€™m finding that when you start playing with the task/environment/self parts, they all start affecting each other in unexpected ways. One of the most intriguing: what itâ€™s doing to what I think words are actually for. Thatâ€™s led to a List of writing questions (see, nice exobrain link; sorry, some LLM assistance in that list). Thereâ€™s a long section on different functions of writing where â€œnarrow professional wordsâ€ are in the minority. Thereâ€™s also writing for oneâ€™s own brain/ psychology/emotions; connection; experimentation; identity buildingâ€¦

That rather solipsistic view segues into bigger veins and arteries we all share. I tried â€œWritingâ€ about that - itâ€™s got some of the ideas there, butâ€¦ too much. Letâ€™s see if itâ€™s possible to pick away at it more slowly. It feels like a very specific historical moment for language, when humans have lost their monopoly on the written word (people pointing that out here, here, here), when the collective lighthouses we used to steer away from the Deathly Rocks of Bullshit are under well-funded, sustained attack.

Thatâ€™s enough to make it feel like finding your own words is pointless. Working theory: it isnâ€™t, itâ€™s more important than ever. So letâ€™s add that one to the list for later:

Footnotes

  1. Hat tip to my partner Helen for bringing her OT background to bear.â†©ï¸

item.title: I wrote a sci-fi book about AI before chatGPT came out. Now what?
item.description:
I wrote a sci-fi book about artificial intelligence. I started the research for it in 2018, from an idea Iâ€™d had in 2012. A first draft was done by mid 2021. After no luck pitching to agents, I lovingly disassembled that draft and put it back together by the following summer in 2022, then churned through another round of agent pitches (also nope).

A few months later, at the end of 2022, openAI released chatGPT 3.5 for public use. Three years have since passed. That Oatmeal panel above (from this piece) is how a lot of people feel now about AI - thereâ€™s a decent chance youâ€™d be willing to pay to make everyone please shut up about it, please stop inserting it into our lives whether we ask for it or no.

Amid this ceaseless cacophony, I am planning to get the book out into the world. Great timing. Iâ€™ve set myself this aim:

Self-publish it, after one more churn cycle, and chart the process here on coveredinbees. Iâ€™m guessing itâ€™ll take six to nine months. Weâ€™ll see how optimistic that is1. I may possibly attempt an Indiegogo launch campaign in the final weeks.

Iâ€™ll be re-assessing the book scene by scene in this final loop, writing about the ideas and the construction of it. It has to remain a product of its pre-chatGPT time. Itâ€™s a bad idea to let current events blow oneâ€™s ideas around like a weathervane. But our brave new LLM world (bubble pop or not) does offer a chance to reflect. How much has it (a) changed how I think about the book and (b) changed how I think about AI and its impact on us?

Iâ€™ll be journaling progress as I go in this planning/work doc (partly to be open, partly a post-LLM urge to demonstrate the flailing human frightfulness of the process).

Anyone who knows me knows I struggle to see the value of my own work. The book has plenty of flaws, but Iâ€™m super-proud of it. This never happens. I feel baffingly, DunningKrugerly confident in it. Iâ€™ve worked hard to mix ideas with pace, to write something fun. Your definition of fun may differ, but I think a certain kind of sci-fi fan (i.e. people like me) will dig it. Iâ€™m going to roll with that feeling before my brain notices.

So stick your email in the subscribe box ifâ€¦

  • Youâ€™re interested in the nuts and bolts of fiction writing and self-publishing (a pretty convoluted process) and want to follow along as I get this done. Maybe youâ€™re especially into sci-fi.
  • Youâ€™re into ideas about how technology and society thread through each other. You may be trying to get under the skin of whatâ€™s actually happening with AI. You might also find yourself drawn to the questions it raises about minds and intelligence, including the collective kind (despite exasperated protests from several / AI / researchers that things like AGI are a dumb distraction).

(Iâ€™ll mark sci-fi related posts, in case you want to avoid other stuff I write about.)

In my day-job, Iâ€™m now working on analysis of AI workplace impacts. Given that, writing about sci-fi feels a bit like running through town wearing nothing but a fez and a feather boa: equally mortifying and liberating, potentially illegal. But itâ€™s how I was schooled - in the last year of my Sheffield politics degree, Mike Kenny paired social theory with sci-fi every week2. I was introduced there to whatâ€™s arguably still my favourite book, Le Guinâ€™s Dispossessed. (We didnâ€™t have to wear just a fez and feather boa in seminars though.) Causal arrows between our imaginations and reality go in all directions (though that has issues - see below).

Whatâ€™s the book about?

People and technology co-evolve. The path they forge together is messy and unpredictable. Sci-fi slips to the edges of this a lot: AI heaven, liberating us from all Earthly drudgery; or a glowing-red-eyed hell where the best we can hope for is that AI wants us as pets. I wanted to dig into the mess more.

Itâ€™s a â€œtwo strands turn into oneâ€ book. Strand #1 explores just how intractably difficult it would be a re-create something as complex as a human mind. Itâ€™s the opposite of Matrix-style â€œstick a cable in this hole and youâ€™re good to goâ€ and other â€œbrain upload = just pop this cap on / lie on this tableâ€ takes that make it look as clean as scanning an item at the checkout. (Recent example: Alien Earth.) Those do have an advantage - just do the upload and get on with the plot. I made a story out of the process itself.

Now, Iâ€™m very very not a neuroscientist. But this is fiction, so hereâ€™s what I did. If brain knowledge is a vast, carefully curated palace full of the most subtle, inscrutable paintings (see e.g. Damasioâ€™s amazing Self Comes to Mind, a book I leaned on a lot), then I broke into that palace at 3am with a swagbag, cut as many pictures out of frames with a Stanley knife as I could and scarpered before the cops arrived.

With that contraband in hand, strand #1 is about what brain upload looks like if we take the complexity of the human meatsack remotely seriously. It naturally fits a wake up in a room3 setting - arguably a steep challenge for a first time fiction author to make that compelling, but I gave it a go. The dreaded C word4 does arise, but in a slightly novel way I hope.

Strand #2: a ripping yarn built on copyright and intellectual property law. Wild. No, stay with me. The idea is that AI will radically alter our relationship with language. Weâ€™re seeing an argument for that erupting into the world right now with LLMs, firmly in â€œwhoa what an unpredictable messâ€ territory.

Again, sci-fiâ€™s natural grain leans to the extremes, authoritarian in this case - e.g. Ma Boyongâ€™s â€œCity of Silenceâ€ short story in Invisible Planets or more recently Where the Axe is Buried; amazing takes on the â€œAI + 1984 style control and destruction of language = what?â€ question.

But if we start from where we are now, with the mire of politics, law and money we swim in, where might the evolving mess take us? Strand #2 is a thought experiment about one of those possible destinations. Thereâ€™s plenty enough darkness in the result, but Iâ€™ve tried to get other shades in there.

There also ended up being a fair dose of Evil Robot. Turns out itâ€™s really difficult to avoid.

Self-publishing?

Yep. And not just because all those failed agent pitches mean itâ€™s the only option, no sirree. This is in no way like a jilted lover wailing, â€œI never wanted you anyway.â€ Hereâ€™s how I comfort myself: self-publishing does actually have some advantages. (â€œI donâ€™t need you, my lifeâ€™s better now!â€) The book may have its niche - TBC - but it was probably never a very commercial proportion5. While Iâ€™ve worked very hard to make the plot bounce along, I have also given all the ideas-y stuff pride of place. Thatâ€™s why I wrote it - I wanted that challenge of trying to make ideas and plot work together. Kill your darlings schmill your schmarlings. I love my darlings and want them to live. Thereâ€™s also a level of control - including what I hope to do here on the blog in the coming months - that would be difficult otherwise. Control, yes. Fame, wealth, accolades, less of that. So it goes.

What next?

Stick around for sci-fi and other ramblings. As well as general progress reports, hereâ€™s some things I might try and write about.

  • Forecasting versus thought experiments in science fiction. Bouncing off Le Guinâ€™s brilliant short intro to the Left Hand of Darkness. As I mentioned, part of my day job is attempting some predictive scenarios of AIâ€™s impact on work (thereâ€™s a little over 30 other reports on this subject Iâ€™ve found, most out in the last two years - everyoneâ€™s at it). Le Guin makes a forceful case that sci-fi shouldnâ€™t be splashing about in those waters: â€œPrediction is the business of prophets, clairvoyants, and futurologists. It is not the business of novelists. A novelistâ€™s business is lying.â€ But the genreâ€™s role in shaping how we conceive our present and future (for better or worse) is an interesting tangle.
  • Creativity. Thereâ€™s a lot of insistence that AI canâ€™t be creative like wot a human can. â€œLike a humanâ€ is probably true, but itâ€™s harder to dismiss AI creativity entirely. There are overlaps between how AI and humans do it. A common line: â€œAI canâ€™t go beyond its training like we can.â€ Really? Iâ€™ve written a similar-ballpark short story that explores this. The issue isnâ€™t the creative divide between meatsack and machine, itâ€™s how the structures we inhabit use and abuse creativity. I should read something by the late Prof. Margaret Boden before I write anything about this.
  • Intelligence. AI engenders some odd views about it. The singularity, for example - the notion that once AI surpasses humans, itâ€™ll start an exponential feedback thatâ€™ll make us to AI as ants are to humans etc etc blah. Uh huh. But we already have systems more intelligent than a human - theyâ€™re called â€˜collections of humansâ€™ and their organisations. Who do you think built London or the 747? Why didnâ€™t they start exponential feedbacks? Positive feedbacks, yes, but they seemed to stabilise - why? What, if anything, does that say about intelligence? That brings up some curious viewpoints - people who think, yes, weâ€™ve made superintelligences like the market system, but only in the way that ants (them again) build complex nests, and we mustnâ€™t presume to interfere etc etc blah. Uh huh. So yeah, fun to be had here.
  • Consciousness. Why thereâ€™s (almost) no point talking about it. We can mark out a space around it - whatâ€™s left after weâ€™ve cut away what can rationally be discussed. But the thing itself? Consciousness is that kid in the Mickey Mouse hat in the Larson cartoon below. Donâ€™t be one of the snakes. (Actually, that might be all there is to say on this subject. I will probably still go on about it.)

Footnotes

  1. Iâ€™ve also committed to not drinking alcohol until the book is out. I really want a beer, this is very motivating. I hope itâ€™s not three or more years.â†©ï¸

  2. Daily Mail headline: â€œWoke university teaching science fiction! This is why we lost the Empire!â€â†©ï¸

  3. Two TV Tropes links there, you may notice. Yep. Iâ€™ve read a lot of stuff on story structure - plenty of people want to sell you the one framework for how stories work - but out of everything Iâ€™ve looked at, TV Tropes is still top. It doesnâ€™t mess around, and is way more up to date on how classic tropes have converted themselves into modern media. And the writing is comic genius.â†©ï¸

  4. I met with a few friends in a little meaning-and-nature-of-consciousness discussion group for a while. You end up chasing yourself in circles very quickly indeed. Iâ€™ll come back to this, though. I have Things To Say. (See the list of possible topics too.)â†©ï¸

  5. You learn how indispensable that is as you dig into traditional publishing - agents have to convince publishers with projected sales numbers alone, usually with â€œx is similar to y and z, and those two are selling well right nowâ€.â†©ï¸

item.title: Prototyping open econ tools
item.description:
Over the past couple of years, Iâ€™ve been building up a loose â€˜regional economicsâ€™ toolkit while digging into UK sectors, growth and other econ-adjacent data (working mainly with SYMCA wearing my Y-PERN hat)1.

Iâ€™m gathering data/code/explanations onto a regecontools website, though bits are spread all over. This live outputs page on the techie blog has gathered most of it in one place. (Fun2 example interactive: South Yorkshireâ€™s job count from 2023 BRES data; click to drill down through local authority and sector granularity.)

Over the next six months or so, I want to make this a more focused project. The plan is roughly this:

  • Using open data/methods, test and improve these tools (and prototype new ones) so theyâ€™re as useful as they can be
  • Dig deeper into the ideas and questions weâ€™re pursuing - iterate between these and the tools.
  • Build on existing relationships and search out new ones to refine the tools/ideas/questions cycle.
  • Help build capacity through things like this ONS Local session I ran introducing R for regional economic analysis (video here; the online slides here work as a how-to guide, including how to use R easily in a browser).

The least tested part of this for me, and maybe the most interesting, is the â€˜tools/ideas/questionsâ€™ cycle. The tools/concepts we use to make sense of our regional economies have grown from a hodgepodge of ideas. These can be questioned at different levels - from narrowly methodological (â€œDo existing measures of public sector output capture their real value? Have we understood what impact boundary choice has?â€) through to deeper, more political ideas about what economies are and what/who theyâ€™re for (see e.g. the latest doughnut economics Nature paper or this survey of over 200 eco-econs/wellbeing indicators).

Y-PERNâ€™s whole purpose has been to experiment with breaking down barriers in this cycle - trying to push past deficit model thinking that just sees that cycle as a â€œtransfer of information from experts to non-expertsâ€. This is still a pretty entrenched view: academics toil in the dark for years, emerge pale and blinking, clutching new insights. A separate â€˜knowledge exchangeâ€™ process then commences.

But that doesnâ€™t align with the reality of data-driven policymaking: everyone involved are experts in what they do. Itâ€™s a deeply collaborative endeavour. We donâ€™t all share the same knowledge, but we also wonâ€™t progress much without bringing everyoneâ€™s together.

The â€˜openâ€™ part of the toolkit is in symbiosis with the â€˜ideas/questionsâ€™ part. Regions face many of the same economic questions, including identical asks from central government (e.g. to produce Local Growth Plans). The same data sources are re-used, the same assumptions. At the same time, weâ€™re all working to develop our own identities as devolution deepens. Given that, hereâ€™s the philosophy I want to work with:

Do data work openly where we can. It will support collaboration and learning. It will help build a shared sense of ground truth. It will avoid wheel reinvention.

I donâ€™t have a dogmatic fealty to open source â€” we have a data/analysis mixed economy where private providers can do things other canâ€™t, and thatâ€™s a good thing. There are also essential datasets that canâ€™t be open, for good reason. But where we can, working in the open just goes better with the grain of those three things: (1) collaborative learning/capacity building across silos; (2) developing our shared sense of ground truth; (3) avoiding wheel reinvention (a facet of reproducibility, which needs open methods; you canâ€™t reproduce something if you canâ€™t access it).

The only way this works is if we prototype. Or call that test and learn if you prefer. As that doc says:

At its simplest [it] involves (1) developing something; (2) making contact with reality; (3) learning from the results.

Sounds great in principle - but we have to be open to our preconceptions being challenged when we smack into reality. The Valve Games employee manual puts it like this3:

â€œâ€”â€“ing up is a great way to find out that your assumptions were wrong or that your model of the world was a little bit off. As long as you update your model and move forward with a better picture, youâ€™re doing it right. Look for ways to test your beliefs. Never be afraid to run an experiment or to collect more data.â€

While not always comfortable, this is part of how to grow our shared sense of ground truth by working together. Itâ€™s perfect â€˜blind people and elephantâ€™ parable territory4. Brace for an extremely mixed elephant/economy metaphor.

  • We want to see as much of the elephant as we can. How is the economy structured, whatâ€™s growing, shrinking, changing? Why? (And a whole bag of less narrow questions, of course.)
  • Those lead naturally to â€œWhat data/methods do we have to answer these questions?â€ Any one data source helps us grab a single pachyderm part. Multiple sources give us a grip on different bits, but the whole beast still eludes us. We need enough knowledge to know our toolsâ€™ limitations - we will regularly hit the streetlight effect, mistaking the data for the whole animal5.

Combining openness and prototyping, though, we can exchange what we think weâ€™ve seen with others, maybe learn from our errors, and move a step or two closer to a collective sense of shape.

Then there are awkward people saying things like, â€œAre we sure this is an elephant? I think maybe we have to go back to first principles here.â€ But again - an open, testing approach lets us argue our competing pachyderm theories out, and often discover diverse tools can be used in different places very effectively despite no total agreement.

That can hit up against very different incentives and cadences across academia and policymaking (as SYMCAâ€™s Alice Rubbra lays out here really clearly) - but those are other elements to test as we go. What mix of relationships and structures can we grow to get closer to truly learning, adaptive regions?

So, what next? Iâ€™ll need to keep things fairly narrow to achieve anything at all, most likely by testing some ONS and Companies-House-extracted economy measures, see what can be improved, what blind spots there are. Iâ€™ll also try to find two or three focused problems to apply this to - including, Iâ€™m hoping, something on how we close the gap between quant views of sector mix and ground level knowledge of how firms interact, and what difference that makes to their success.

Underlying-idea-wise, Iâ€™d like to see how older theories of technical changes in production can help shed light on current AI fears (Iâ€™m also working on an AI impact project). That could help think through where we want economic progress to come from.

Letâ€™s see how contact with reality changes things. Stick your email in the subscribe box to follow alongâ€¦

Footnotes

  1. Github commit of this doc with cuttings at the bottom.â†©ï¸

  2. If you find this kind of thing entertainingâ€¦â†©ï¸

  3. Not an endorsement of Valveâ€™s supposedly desk-on-wheels culture or anything similar. As this article explores, structures like this (including some co-ops without explicit rules) can often just obscure hidden hierarchies, making them harder to navigate or challenge.â†©ï¸

  4. Elephant parable example applied to economics.â†©ï¸

  5. Krugman: â€œWe just donâ€™t see what we canâ€™t formaliseâ€. [citation forgotten!]â†©ï¸
